I'm a bit unsure about the statistic saying that in the US, 20% of meals are eaten in a car. From what I can find, that number came from John Nihoff, but other sources found far different results:

"John Nihoff, a professor of gastronomy at the Culinary Institute of America, says about 19 percent of our meals are consumed in cars – though his definition of "meals" includes in-between snacks like doughnuts or a bag of carrots.

Kelton Research, polling 1,000 people for Taco Bell this summer, found the portion of people who say they eat in the car at least once a day (9 percent) was eclipsed by the number of people who say they never eat in the car (31 percent).

The market researcher NPD Group says the average person ate 32 restaurant meals – including snacks like cones - in the car last year. That's up from 19 in 1984."

It should be noted that several of the places ranked above the U.S. in life expectancy are not "nations" but very small territories belonging to the U.S. (U.S. Virgin Islands), Denmark (Faroe Islands), France (St. Pierre and Miquelon--population 6,080) or the U.K. (British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Isle of Man, Bermuda, Jersey, Guernsey, and Anguilla).  Some others are similarly tiny but wealthy nations (Liechtenstein, Andorra, San Marino, and Monaco).  Iceland and Malta each have fewer than half a million people, and Luxembourg has less than 600,000.  There are actually just a few countries on that list that are relatively comparable to the U.S. in terms of geographic and demographic size and diversity.

I honestly hate how we have so much division in this world. But people often feel more comfortable in their own tribe and it's easy to label others. I live in America, but I'm a human first. I don't care if you're American or any other nationality. I will judge you as a person, an individual, not by your race or where you were born. It's a shame the division isn't just what I see in the comment section pitting America against Europe or Canada, etc...

It also stems internally as well. Let's say someone from Europe bashes America. That would be on a larger scale. Yet in America, we might bash each other if you live in a different state. Ex. California for being liberal, Alabama for being conservative. Then within those states, we bash towns or cities we deem trashier or less than us. Then within those towns and cities we bash groups of people we don't identify with. Then within those groups of people we might bash people in our closest of circles in our family and friends group. It just continues with division no matter how far inwards or outwards you go. It's the tribe mentality.

Though, for all of you bashing each others' countries in the comments section, imagine an alien race looking down on Earth bashing it saying it's a terrible planet, and now you all are part of the group as a whole. Or yet another alien race bashing the Milky Way galaxy for being a crappy galaxy and Andromeda is the superior galaxy. It can continue on much larger scales as well as you see. So what should this tell us? How about start judging people individually, or maybe don't even judge them at all and lump everyone into a category knowing nothing about them.

I may live in America, but many of these statistics in this video do not apply to me or many people I know whatsoever. So how about start spreading loving kindness to one another? Stop judging people on their race or sexuality or where they were born or live. Start spreading more positivity and helping others become their best version and encourage one another. We are all part of the human race, and we need to take care of each other in order to strive and survive. Be the change you want to create and help do your part to make this world a better place, and that starts with loving one another!

Americans don't want to produce more waste and use more of the Earth's resources, but we're victims of a system that not only allows it, but encourages it.

And the more opinions there are, the more likely you are to see opinion diversity. More people to spread different ideas across the internet. Two, humans are pack animals/herd animals. If other people have a negative opinion about the US, then it's okay for me to have a negative opinion as well. The group with the negative opinion will gain popularity by reaching to people without an opinion and eventually becoming an overwhelming number. Soon, extremists will form in your group. Media will focus on extremist beliefs and exaggerate them, and people overseas will read it. Thats why you see such negativity towards the United States.

I'm Canadian.

1. To the people making the argument that people are bashing Americans, but we do a lot is completely off the wall. Just because we do a lot does not mean that we are entitled to do what we want how we want. I may identify as a Republican Independent, but that type of logic is so far conservative that it is not reasonable anymore.
2. Yes, we do a lot. Yes, we are a larger country. Yes, we will produce more waste and things of the sort compared to certain smaller countries, so let's put some of their data (which felt very blatantly Democratic and passive aggressive) into that perspective.
3. We could and should change how certain things are taken care of in the country such as trash, emissions, health care, etc... but our political system controls all these issues, and it is so far polarized from the usage of social media that there is a high chance little will happen about it except arguing.
4. Disclaimer: This is not a point as much as a note to those reading this and looking for a reason to argue... probably quite violently. I know I talked of my political thoughts and made a remark on theirs then proceed to say that things are too politically polarized. I am saying this as separate points and ideas. So, my point is that this data is more or less organized and presented in a way that supports a more Democratic viewpoint which is okay, but we need to consider the opposite side before arguing the DATA. On the note of the political polarization, I am saying that because we have issues to address, but we have a system where if we even remotely step on another person's feet it's shut down. I'm not saying it's okay to freely pass bills and do things just to try it or what have you, but I do think our current ideals and system make it so passing anything or addressing any issue is a bit too open for argument when certain small things could just be tested out instead of argued over for extended periods of time before even getting to the yes/no on passing it.

Actually there isn't need to speculate on Americans life expectancy. Pretty well every study shows our life expectancy is most largely impacted by more sedantary lifestyle and one of the highest stress levels in the world. You have additional factors such as more people dying in auto accidents and due to violence, both of which tend to happen at younger ages, that eschew our numbers. And obviously you also have dietary issues though it is extremely difficult to tell if our largest issue is diet or lack of activity. Most of our research now is showing it has more to do with lifestyle than diet, thus the campaigns encouraging movement.

Not sure where they got the idea that publicly funded healthcare had any involvement in it (perhaps just political bias??) but none of our research has shown any advantage when viewed on a per individual basis. America actually has one of the highest rates of cancer remission in the world as well the highest rate of functional diabetic treatment in the world. This indicates our healthcare is functioning at a high level (treatment not costs, separate issues). Frequently for political purposes these numbers are manipulated by holding the increased instances of diabetes and heart disease (sadly we are leaders here) against our healthcare system even though these are lifestyle metrics, not treatment metrics.

Well, despite being bad for the world, most people in the world like the more important aspects of american lifestyle:

- cheap houses/flats (mostly, with notably exceptions like SF and NY), cheap food, cheap gas etc.
- wide, open and mostly empty land (my country's pop.density is 8 times higher)
- extensive freedom in certain areas (like selfdefense), although this is heavily counteracted by many other things, e.g drinking

Plus the US happen to have nice nature and nice climate (mostly).

So, of course most people would like that, including me. The world is just too small for it to happen for everyone.
Some things may be archieved by technological progress (cheaper energy and food for everyone), but some won't happen
(wasteful usage of land and other resources).

With more people in the world, pressure on the US will rise to change certain things, which will be good for everyone.

If you're proudly from, say,  England or Finland (love ya'll!) and balk at the U.S. standard of living, and then your children emigrate to the States, your lineage goes there too and joins its numbers. Many people in the U.S. are cultured, well-traveled, informed of the global scenario and participate in activism, compassionate, conscious lifestyles and celebrate (and vehemently defend!) ethnic diversity. Outside of the embarrassing display of mindless waste, bigotry and general small-minded mass kool-aid consumption that denotes the reputation of the U.S. mindscape, it's also a country of wondrous national parks, breathtaking mountain ranges, deserts, canyons, massive lakes, a broad range of unique wildlife, bohemian university towns, cultural hubs, festivals, open roads for days, camping and outdoor lifestyles, innovative ecological movements and the list goes on. It's got the Grand Canyon! Yellowstone! New York! Seattle, The Great Lakes, the Mojave Desert. The Appalachian Trail. Ever seen the stars at night or cry of a loon in Ely, Minnesota? In every one of these places are people of significance fighting to preserve, protect, restore these gems that comprise the United States. Those residing in the U.S. are not just Americans--which spans all of the Americas. There seems to be a lot of hate for Americans here, but what would some of the positive effects be? For one, if everyone lived like Americans, world hunger and malnutrition would be eliminated, and nearly 100% of Earth's population would have access to clean water, indoor plumbing and sanitation, and electricity. Access to vaccinations would be widespread, and many diseases would be eliminated, especially water-borne diseases. Almost 0% of women world-wide would die in childbirth. Birth rates would fall and global population totals would level off or drop.

Global literacy rates would reach nearly 100%, and all women would have access to education. For that matter, all children would have access to education. Nearly every family would have multiple televisions and computers, and access to the internet.

Female circumcision would be eliminated. Modern slavery would reach all time lows. Capitalism would replace communism and banana republics, and per-capita GDP would skyrocket. Working conditions would improve and unemployment rates would fall, and wages would increase.

Autocracies would fall and be replaced with democracy. We would have no war in Syria. North Korea would start feeding its own people. Russia would stop invading and annexing bordering countries, and stop meddling in other democracies' elections. And since democracies are historically less likely to go to war against one another and less likely to harbor terrorist cells, a period of global peace would be likely.

With the entire world now having a higher standard of living and higher levels of education, technological advancement would increase by leaps and bounds. Space exploration would rapidly increase as well.
